text: An Argentine pastafrola in a baking tray Pasta frola (),Πάστα φλώρα . Argiro. Retrieved on 2019-04-25. is a type of sweet tart common to Argentina, Paraguay, Uruguay, Egypt and Greece. ¡A merendar una pastafrola!. . Ella. Retrieved on 2015-03-23. Πάστα φρόλα: έτσι λέγεται στην πραγματικότητα η πάστα…φλώρα . INews.gr (2011-04-02). Retrieved on 2015-03-23. It is a covered, jam-filled shortcrust pastry dish principally made from flour, sugar and egg.pastaflora . Diccionario de la lengua española (22.ª edición), Real Academia Española (2001). Common fillings include quince cheese, dulce de batata (sweet potato jam), dulce de leche, guava, or strawberry jam. The covering of the tart is a thin-striped lattice which displays the filling beneath in square sections. Pastafrola is most usually oven-baked in a circular shape. Most of the Greek versions of this dish are filled with sweet jam: it is considered a morning dessert. The name of the dish comes from pasta frolla, Italian for shortcrust pastry, and is similar to the Italian crostata. Italian immigrants brought it to Argentina and Uruguay. Pasta Frola de Dulce de Membrillo - Quince Tart. About. Retrieved on 2015-03-23. Similar dishes include the Austrian Linzer torte and Swiss tarts with a spiced-fruit filling.Pastafrola y sus ancestros . La Nación (2002-07-14). Retrieved on 2015-03-23. The dish is served as an afternoon dessert (merienda) or with mate (a South American drink), but may be eaten at any time of the day. ==Ingredients== The ingredients for the dish are: Greek jam tart (Pasta flora). Retrieved on 2015-03-23. *Flour *Egg *Sugar *Butter or margarine *Jam filling (most common are quince, sweet potato jam, dulce de leche, guava, or strawberry) *Lemon zest *Vanilla extract ==References== Category:Argentine cuisine Category:Uruguayan desserts Category:Italian pastries Category:Greek pastries Category:Paraguayan cuisine Category:Guava dishes Category:Cheese dishes Category:Tarts Category:Pasta dishes
